awd_titl_txt: SusChEM: Interfacial Interactions and Electron Transfer in Dye-Sensitized Systems for Photovoltaics and Photocatalysis
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanism B Program (CSDMB) of the Chemistry Division is supporting the research of Professor Kristin Wustholz of the Department of Chemistry at the College of William and Mary to study organic dye-sensitized systems for use in next-generation solar energy conversion materials and devices. Organic dye sensitizers are molecules that can be used to harvest sunlight for energy related applications. They work by absorbing the light needed to excite an electron in the dye to a higher energy level. This high energy electron is then transferred to a semiconducting material. The use of an organic dye sensitizer for this effort is particularly attractive because they are made of earth-abundant, inexpensive materials. However, their use also comes with a cost in that their use is frequently complicated by the low efficiency of electron-transfer between the dye and the semiconductor and the poor long-term stability of the dye-semiconductor complex. The goal of this project is to solve these problems by learning how to optimize the light-harvesting ability of organic dye sensitizers while maintaining both the electron-transfer efficiency and stability of the dye-semiconductor complexes. By addressing these problems, the Wustholz group is contributing to efforts to address current issues related to the growing demand for renewable energy. At the same time, the research is providing meaningful research and developmental experiences for undergraduate and master's degree students who are being trained in physical, analytical, and materials chemistry. During the budget period, the Wustholz group is continuing its efforts to develop the research and communication skills of underrepresented students through long-term, mentored research experiences, as well as outreach activities that are aimed at increasing the number of such students that are exposed to meaningful scientific experiences. 

The central goal of this project is to understand the interfacial interactions and electron-transfer processes occurring in organic-dye-based systems for dye-sensitized solar cells and photocatalysis. Organic dye sensitizers consist of earth-abundant elements, possess high absorption coefficients, and have the potential for enhanced light harvesting through controlled surface aggregation. In this work, the Wustholz group will pursue three main strategies to understand and optimize the optical and electronic properties of organic-dye-based systems for solar-to-electrical and solar-to-fuel conversion: 1) determine the structure-activity relationships of surface-aggregated organic dyes, 2) elucidate the interfacial electron-transfer processes and kinetic dispersion at the molecular level, and 3) probe the impact of operational variables on molecular aggregation and interfacial kinetics for surface-anchored organic dyes. This project contributes to our fundamental understanding of solar energy conversion and to the development of new approaches to efficiently convert solar photons into chemical energy.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Many systems that convert solar energy into a usable form (electricity or fuel) rely on rare and costly inorganic materials that, while robust, limit the widespread growth of the solar energy sector. Semiconducting nanoparticles decorated with organic dyes are promising alternatives since they are inexpensive, Earth-abundant, and highly-absorbing materials for harnessing solar energy. However, organic dyes suffer from poor long-term stability and low efficiency of the electron transfer (ET) processes that are required for solar energy conversion. In this project, researchers learned how organic dyes arrange, decompose, and transfer electrons at the semiconductor interface, with the overall goal of developing design strategies for enhanced organic-dye-based materials for solar energy conversion.

A main outcome of this project was determining how organic dyes form clusters or aggregates on a semiconducting TiO2 surface, which can significantly impact ET. Our initial work targeted rhodamine dyes, which had been reported to form head-to-head or H aggregates that exhibit enhanced ET efficiency. Although the spectral properties of rhodamine-doped TiO2 are indeed modified relative to solution, which would be indicative of H aggregation, these effects are not observed for rhodamines bearing primary amines or on insulating surfaces. Collectively, the results show that rhodamines containing substituted amines do not appreciably H-aggregate on TiO2 ? they actually photodecompose via N-dealkylation. The dealkylated rhodamines form weakly fluorescent head-to-tail or J aggregates on TiO?2, which exhibit enhanced ET efficiency relative to monomers. With this knowledge, strategies to control the aggregation and photodecomposition of organic dyes can be developed to enhance ET and stability for solar energy conversion applications.

A second outcome of the project was elucidating the ET dynamics of organic-dye-sensitized systems for photocatalysis down to the level of single molecules. One of the advantages of studying complex systems like dye-doped semiconductors one molecule at a time is the ability to reveal the full distribution of behavior, not just the average of the ensemble. Our initial studies in this area focused on eosin, an organic dye used in solar-to-fuel systems. By removing the effects of ensemble averaging and molecular aggregation using single-molecule spectroscopy, we found that eosin-doped TiO2 exhibits tremendous dispersion in ET ? an unwanted effect that limits solar energy conversion efficiency. We untangled the factors governing this dispersion, focusing on the impact of environmental heterogeneity versus contributions from multiple excited states. Ultimately, the results demonstrated that dynamic fluctuations in binding configuration and/or vibrational motion at the eosin-semiconductor interface govern unwanted dispersion. In addition to highlighting the need to minimize dispersion, perhaps via covalent attachment of dyes to TiO2, a secondary outcome of this research was the development of new methods for analyzing the emission from single molecules. These publicly-available tools will be useful for researchers seeking to utilize single-molecule methods to probe complex environments, such as in solar cells, nanomaterials, biological environments, and polymers, the results of which have broad impacts in technology and medicine.

A total of 16 students, 12 undergraduates, 2 master?s students, and 2 students who received both B.S. and M.S. degrees received training under this grant. These trainees were >50% women and included members of groups underrepresented in the sciences. Students were trained not only in lab techniques but also in scientific communication and the process of taking a project from an idea to the lab, and ultimately, a conference presentation and published paper. Eight students directly supported by the grant contributed to conference presentations at the Inter-American Photochemical Society (two students won undergraduate poster awards) and Southeast Regional American Chemical Society meetings. In collaboration with William & Mary?s National Organization for the Professional Advancement of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers (NOBCChE) chapter, the principal investigator and her research students took part in outreach activities with local high school students, presenting demonstrations and information about careers in chemistry. 


Last Modified: 01/07/2023
Modified by: Kristin L Wustholz
